cs.DS, cs.CC, cs.FL, cs.LG, cs.IT. 

The paper deals with the compressed representation of trees, which is a fundamental problem in computer science. The use of string grammars, specifically straight-line programs (SLPs), is a novel approach to this problem. Therefore, the most likely category is cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms), which deals with the study of data structures and algorithms for organizing, storing, and manipulating data. 

The paper also discusses the efficiency of SLPs in performing various tree queries, which involves computational complexity. This suggests that the paper may also belong to cs.CC (Computational Complexity), which deals with the study of the inherent difficulty of computational problems. 

Furthermore, the paper discusses the comparison of SLPs with tree straight-line programs (TSLPs), which are a type of context-free grammar. This suggests that the paper may also belong to cs.FL (Formal Languages and Automata Theory), which deals with the study of formal languages, grammars, and automata. 

The paper also discusses the succinctness of SLPs, which is related to information theory. This suggests that the paper may also belong to cs.IT (Information Theory), which deals with the study of the quantification, storage, and communication of information. 

Finally, the paper presents experimental results on the performance of SLPs, which suggests that the paper may also belong to cs.LG (Machine Learning
